conclusion: The problem involves determining how shadows A, B, C, and D change in position and size when the light source moves to the back right.
The current light source position is at the front left, casting shadows to the right.
The image shows an apple (A), paper (B), glass (C), and drumstick (D) with their shadows cast to the right.
The light source is moving to the back right, meaning it will illuminate objects from behind and to the right.
Shadows will move in the opposite direction of the light, shifting to the left and front.
The shadow of the apple (A) will move to the left and elongate slightly.
The shadow of the paper (B) will move to the left and may become more elongated.
The shadow of the glass (C) will move to the left and slightly elongate.
The shadow of the drumstick (D) will move to the left and elongate.
Shadows will generally become longer due to the new angle of the light, which will cast them further away from the objects.
All shadows (A, B, C, D) will move to the left and slightly forward.
When the light source moves to the back right, shadows A, B, C, and D will shift to the left and forward, and they will become longer.
